study_title: Multimodal Cognitive Load Assessment in Expert Programming: A Cross-Cultural Analysis of Software Development Patterns
study_objective: Investigate cognitive load patterns, visual attention distribution, and neural correlates during complex software development tasks across different programming paradigms, IDE configurations, and cultural contexts using synchronized eye tracking, EEG, and physiological monitoring
paradigm: multimodal cognitive load assessment in software engineering with cross-cultural validation and real-time adaptive interfaces
task_description: Expert programmers from diverse cultural backgrounds perform authentic software development tasks including: (1) debugging legacy code in unfamiliar architectures, (2) implementing real-time algorithms under performance constraints, (3) conducting code reviews with collaborative decision-making, (4) refactoring complex enterprise systems, and (5) designing API interfaces with security considerations. All tasks performed under controlled cognitive load manipulation with simultaneous eye tracking (600Hz), high-density EEG (64 channels), heart rate variability, and pupillometry.
institution: Advanced Human-Computer Interaction Lab, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
collaborating_institutions: Technical University Munich - Chair of Ergonomics
University of Tokyo - Digital Fabrication Lab
Universidad de Chile - Department of Computer Science

funding.agency: Japan Society for Promotion of Science

data_availability: Data will be made available via OSF repository upon publication, with anonymized datasets and full analysis pipelines
